journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering

title-group.article-title: Newton iterative method for potential flow problems based on variational principle and finite element type solution

article-meta.aff: 1Shanghai Institute of Applied Mathematics and Mechanics, Shanghai University, China
2Shanghai Key Laboratory of Mechanics in Energy and Environment Engineering, China
3School of Mechanical Engineering of Nantong University, China

author-notes.corresp: Dian-Gui Huang, Shanghai Institute of Applied Mathematics and Mechanics, Shanghai University, Shanghai, 200072, China. Email: dghuang@shu.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © Shanghai University 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this article, a new method is presented for simulation of incompressible flow field, which is called Newton iteration based on variational finite element method. Meanwhile, underlying theories and general steps in the solution procedure using this method have been described in detail. In order to validate this method, incompressible simulations on the flowfield around a circular cylinder were conducted. The achieved results were then compared with existing analytic solutions and good agreements have been obtained. In addition, the incompressible flow around an aerofoil was also calculated using both the proposed method and the conventional variational finite element method. It was found that the results obtained by the two methods were exactly the same; however, this proposed method can significantly improve the computational efficiency.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: According to eternal law of the material, Newton’s second law and the conservation of energy, fluid flow and associated phenomena observed in nature can be directly described through the use of a set of corresponding differential equations together with boundary conditions. In addition, they can also be indirectly expressed in terms of variational principle that is the extreme value of a functional equation. The advantage of using variational principle to describe the physical processes1 is that the developed model has a compact simple form and can also make full use of its unique natural boundary condition. In the past ten years, the vigorous development of finite element method has made it possible for variational principle to be widely applied to solve various problems in fluid dynamics. Extensive research has been conducted on the use of variational finite element method to solve the forward, inverse, hybrid and related problems arising in fluid flow. At present, many fruitful results have been achieved.2–6 The basic idea of the variational finite element method is to construct the corresponding expression of functional equation and then apply calculus of variations technique to it. When the value of unknown quantities making the extreme points of the constructed functional equation appear, this value of unknown quantities is therefore the desired solution of the flow field.

On the basis of optimization theory, an objective function needs to be established in the first place and the optimal value of the objective function can be subsequently obtained by maximizing or minimizing the objective function. There are different approaches to calculate extreme values of the objective function, among which Newton iteration is one of the most commonly recognized methods. As long as the objective function is second-order continuously differentiable, Newton iteration method can be quite effective for solving optimization problems. Hitherto, the functional expressions of many propositions about fluid mechanics have been given4,5 and most of them are second-order continuously differentiable. As a result, this article proposes a new method, which attempts to take the variational principle as the objective function and adopt Newton’s iterative method to solve the flow fields.

sec.title: Newton’s iterative method
sec.p: It is very effective to solve a problem like min{f(xk)| x ∈ Rn} using Newton’s iteration,7 if f(x) is second-order continuously differentiable. In the neighborhood of xk, the second-order differential of f(x) is approximated to g(x) as follows g(x)=f(xk)+(x-xk)T∇f(xk) +12(x-xk)TH(xk)(x-xk)

In the above equation, H(xk)=∇2f(xk), which is called the Hesse matrix of f(x). The extreme values of g(x) can thus be obtained by setting ∇g(x)=0, namely ∇f(xk)+H(xk)(x-xk)=0. If H(xk) is reversible, then we can get the well-known Newton’s iteration formula below, wherein the superscript k represents the k-th iterative step (1)xk+1=xk-H(xk)-1∇f(xk)

sec.title: Functional analysis for incompressible potential flow
sec.p:
In our first attempt at using Newton’s iteration to solve a flowfield problem, we used a two-dimensional incompressible potential flow as an example whose equations of motion as well as Bernoulli’s equation are given below (2)∇2φ=0
(3)pρ+12 (u2+v2 )=B where φ is the potential function, φx=u, φy=v, velocity vector is q→=ui→+vj→, u and v are the velocity components along x and y directions, respectively.

The functional differential equation is shown below (4)J(φ)=12∫∫(A) [ (∂φ∂x )2+ (∂φ∂y )2 ]dxdy -∫∂A (∂φ∂n )pr·φds where subscript pr presents a pre-set value, n denotes the normal vector at the boundary of the computational domain and A is the computational domain.

sec.title: Far-field boundary conditions
sec.p: (5)φ=φpr or qn=(qn)pr where φpr and (qn )pr are the values of potential function and normal velocity pre-set at the far-field boundary, respectively.

sec.title: Boundary conditions on body surface
sec.p: (6)qn=(qn)pr or (ui→+vj→ )·n→=0 where n→ is normal vector on body surface.

sec.title: Boundary conditions on the surface of trailing vortex
sec.p: (7)p+=p- and (qn )+= (qn )- where p+ is the pressure close up to the upper surface of trailing vortex, and p− is the pressure close up to the under surface of trailing vortex. (qn )+ is the normal velocity close up to the upper surface of trailing vortex, and (qn )- is the normal velocity close up to the under the surface of trailing vortex.

sec.title: Kutta condition at trail point
sec.p: (8)φ+=φ-+Γ where Γ is the velocity circulation pre-seted.

sec.title: Solution procedures using finite element method with Newton iterations
Preliminary preparation
sec.p: The physical plane is divided into a series of quadrilateral elements firstly, and then all the functions within one quadrilateral element are calculated using bilinear interpolation. Consequently, the following expressions can be gotten (9) {φ (ξ,η )=∑i=1 4Ni (ξ,η )φix (ξ,η )=∑i=1 4Ni (ξ,η )xiy (ξ,η )=∑i=1 4Ni (ξ,η )yi where (xi,yi ) is the coordinates of the i-th vertex of the element in the physical plane, φi is the potential function for the i-th vertex (10) {N1 (ξ,η )=14 (1-ξ ) (1-η )N2 (ξ,η )=14 (1+ξ ) (1-η )N3 (ξ,η )=14 (1+ξ ) (1+η )N4 (ξ,η )=14 (1-ξ ) (1+η )
Also, the Jacobian of transformation is defined to be [Ja ]=∂ (x,y )∂ (ξ,η )

Therefore, a corresponding relationship between the rectangular unit and the isoparametric element has been established. Meanwhile, the surface integral of the original integral functional has become the surface integral over the standard isoparametric element E, as shown in equation (11) (11)∫∫(A) (… )dxdy=∫∫(E) (… ) |Ja |dξdη

Furthermore, we can get the following equations (12) {∂JE∂φi=-∫∫E1 |Ja | {∑j=1 4(BNiξNjξ-CNiξNjη+ANiηNjη -CNiηNjξ)φj }dξdη+∫∫∂En→·(ρui→+ρvj→)Nids∂2JE∂φi∂φj=-∫∫E1 |Ja |(BNiξNjξ-CNiξNjη+ANiηNjη -CNiηNjξ)dξdη where A=xξ 2+yξ 2, B=xη 2+yη 2, C=xξxη+yξyη.
It can be easily seen from the above equations (12) that under the incompressible assumption, ∂2JE∂φi∂φj is only related to the geometrical parameters and has nothing to do with velocity potential.

sec.title: Provision of initial condition
sec.p: The appropriate initial condition φi 0 is selected by considering the actual situations.

sec.title: Newton’s iteration
sec.p: The iterative equations (13) and (14) shown below can be obtained by applying equation (1) (13)φk+1=φk-H(φk)-1∇J(φk) where φ is a vector composed of potential functions for all vertices (14) {H(φk)= [∂2JE∂φ1∂φ1 ∂2JE∂φ1∂φ2….∂2JE∂φ1∂φM∂2JE∂φ2∂φ1 ∂2JE∂φ2∂φ2….∂2JE∂φ2∂φM:∂2JE∂φM∂φ1 ∂2JE∂φM∂φ2….∂2JE∂φM∂φM ]∇J(φk)= [∂JE∂φ1∂JE∂φ2:∂JE∂φM ]

Subscript M in the equation above indicates the total number of vertices. Hence, substitution of equation (12) into equation (14) yields the Hessex matrix H(φk) and functional gradient ΔJ(φk). As Hessex matrix H has no relation to φ for incompressible flows, the calculation of the inverse of matrix H is conducted only once.

Applying initial condition and using equation (13), we can conduct the iterative process. When the maximum difference between the velocity potential obtained at two successive iterations is less than a predefined value, the calculation is considered complete and the velocity potential obtained at the end of iterations is the solution for the flow field.

sec.title: Example 1
sec.p: In order to validate our method, the incompressible flow field around a circular cylinder has been studied as there exists an analytic solution in this example.

Figure 1 illustrates the computational mesh (21 * 81) that is applied. Figure 2 demonstrates the pressure distribution on the surface of cylinder and this result shows that the proposed method has a good agreement with the analytical solution. The equipotential lines and streamlines around the cylinder that are computed by the proposed method are displayed in Figures 3 and 4, respectively. Figure 1.
The computational mesh.
Figure 2.
The pressure distribution on the surface of cylinder.
Figure 3.
The equipotential lines computed by the finite element method with Newton’s iteration.
Figure 4.
The streamlines computed by the finite element method with Newton’s iteration.

Through the above calculation, it has also been found that if double-precision variables are employed in the computer program, the converged solution can be obtained after only one iteration, regardless of their initial values. In this example, if the given initial values of the potential function are 0, 10, 1000 and 1,000,000 respectively, the corresponding accuracy reached is 10–12, 10–13, 10–11 and 10–7. Thus, for incompressible flow problems, using this method has no strict requirement on the given initial value, which can either be a uniform flow field or even an unrealistic large value.

In an attempt to explain only one iteration required for solving the incompressible flow, we need to look at the solution process applying Newton’s iteration method to a problem with one self-variable. Given a function f(x), its graph is the curve y = f(x), which is shown in Figure 5. Newton’s iteration is then applied to get the values x for f(x) = 0. At first, an initial value x0 is defined and the tangent line to y = f(x) at x = x0 crosses the x-axis at x = x1. Subsequently, we can replace x0 by x1 and repeat the previous step until the desired results are achieved. However, it is worth noting that when the equation f(x) = 0 is a linear equation, the graph of y = f(x) has become a straight line, which is coincident with the tangent line to y = f(x) at x = x0. As a result, the point of intersection of the tangent line to y = f(x) with the x-axis is identical to the intersection point of the line y = f(x) with the x-axis. In other words, when y = f(x) is a linear equation, only one iteration is required to obtain the final result no matter what initial value of x are given. Figure 5.
Schematic diagram of the curve y = f(x) and its tangent.

For incompressible flow, the potential function is a linear partial differential equation, which can be clearly seen from equation (2) introduced in ‘Functional analysis for incompressible potential flow’ section of this article. All the examples discussed in this article have shown that, no matter what the initial value is provided, only one iteration is needed to get the precise distribution of potential function by using Newton’s iterative method. However, at present, there is no adequate theoretical support for this finding.

sec.title: Example 2
sec.p:
As another example, the incompressible flow field around a NACA0012 airfoil at Mach number 0.1 and angle of attack of 4 degree is simulated using Newton’s iterative method. A mesh with 21 × 81 points was adopted in the calculation and is displayed in Figure 6. Figure 6.
Computational grid for the flow field around NACA0012 airfoil.

At the beginning of calculation, uniform initial condition of potential flow has been given. As discussed above, no matter if the initial value was 0, 1 or 10, only one iteration is needed to produce sufficiently accurate results.

The pressure distribution and the streamlines over the NACA0012 airfoil are calculated using the proposed finite element method with Newton’s iteration and plotted in Figures 7 and 8. Figure 7.
Calculated isobar lines over the NACA0012 airfoil.
Figure 8.
Streamlines around the NACA0012 airfoil at 4° angle of attack.

A comparison of pressure coefficients along the airfoil computed by the proposed method and the conventional variational finite element method is presented in Figure 9. Despite different methods, the obtained pressure coefficients are exactly the same. Therefore, the method presented in this article is reliable and feasible, since variational finite element method is already very mature method being used to solve the problem of potential flow around two-dimensional airfoils. However, in contrast to the variational finite element method, which requires several hundred, possibly even thousands of iterations to reach an accurate solution for such potential flow problems, this finite element method with Newton’s iteration needs only one iteration to get the final solution and thus can be apparently two orders of magnitude faster with almost no accuracy loss. Figure 9.
Comparison results of surface pressure coefficients for the NACA0012 airfoil.

sec.title: Discussion and conclusions
sec.p: Fluid flow can be indirectly expressed in terms of variational principle. When the value of unknown quantities makes the extreme points of the variational principle appear, this value of unknown quantities is therefore the desired solution of the flow field. A method, which is used to acquire the extreme points of this variational principle, called Newton iteration based on variational finite element method, is presented for simulation of incompressible flow field is this article.

This method has proven successful after comparing the obtained results with the analytical solutions. In addition, the flow field around an airfoil at a Mach number of 0.1 is also calculated by the proposed method and the obtained result shows good agreement with that reached by the conventional variational finite element method. Thus, the new method has proven to be reliable and feasible.

This research has found that for incompressible potential flow, this new method need only one iteration to get an accurate solution regardless of any given initial values. Consequently, the computational time can be significantly reduced.

The purpose of this article is mainly to present a new finite element method with Newton’s iteration by giving a clear description of its underlying theory and solution steps. Relatively simple problems like incompressible potential flow have been discussed in this article as they can quickly and easily verify the feasibility and reliability of this new method. In fact, the proposed method is particularly effective for solving non-linear problems. Therefore, the study on the application of this method to the forward, inverse and hybrid problems in compressible flow will be carried out in the future.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China Grant No. 50836006, No. 10972133 and No. 91130027, Shanghai Science and Technology Committee with Grant No. 09JC1405800, the High Tech. Research and Development (863) Program (Grant No. 2011AA040202) and Shanghai Program for Innovative Research Team in Universities.
